summary: '**noun / mastering process.** The process of cutting a vinyl master directly.
definition: **noun / mastering process.** The process of cutting a vinyl master directly from original open-reel analog tape as opposed to a digital remaster. This all-analog chain preserves the warmth, dynamics, and tonal characteristics of the original master tape without digital conversion artifacts. Studios use professional tape machines—typically Studer, Ampex, or Scully decks—to play back ¼-inch or ½-inch master tapes at 15 or 30 IPS (inches per second) directly into the cutting lathe. The practice became a premium selling point in the audiophile market during the 1990s and 2000s as labels like Analogue Productions, Music Matters, and Mobile Fidelity emphasized tape-sourced reissues. Engineers must carefully assess tape condition, as oxide shedding and print-through can compromise decades-old masters. When executed properly with well-preserved tapes, open-reel transfers often reveal superior high-frequency extension and spatial information compared to digital intermediaries, making them highly sought after by collectors willing to pay premium prices for sonically authentic pressings.
etymology: Term emerged in the 1990s audiophile market as labels began distinguishing all-analog mastering chains from increasingly common digital remasters, emphasizing the use of original open-reel tape machines.
